items.prompt: When a partner becomes less emotionally responsive, I worry that the relationship is in danger.
I find it difficult to relax when I am uncertain about a partner’s feelings toward me.
Periods of emotional distance make me feel uneasy, even if nothing explicit is wrong.
Too much emotional closeness can make me feel restricted or overwhelmed.
I become uncomfortable when a partner expects a high level of emotional dependence.
I need personal space to feel balanced in a relationship.
I prefer to manage my emotional needs without relying heavily on a partner.
Maintaining a sense of independence is essential for me in close relationships.
I feel most stable when I know I can function well on my own.
My emotional well-being is closely tied to my partner’s emotional state.
When my relationship feels uncertain, it affects how I see myself.
I feel most grounded when my partner and I are emotionally in sync.
Describe a situation in which you felt most secure in a romantic relationship. What specifically contributed to that sense of security? (3–5 sentences)
Describe a time when closeness in a relationship felt uncomfortable or threatening. What made it feel that way? (3–5 sentences)
When a partner becomes emotionally distant, what do you tend to assume is happening, and how do you usually respond internally? (3–5 sentences)
When conflict arises, I feel an immediate urge to address it head-on.
I become more emotionally intense when I feel misunderstood.
Strong emotions come up quickly for me during relational conflict.
My instinct during conflict is to take space rather than continue the discussion.
I often postpone difficult conversations to reduce immediate tension.
When emotions run high, I prefer to withdraw and regroup on my own.
During conflict, I struggle to access or express what I am feeling.
I become quiet or emotionally still when situations feel overwhelming.
I suppress my reactions to prevent conflict from escalating.
After conflict, I am usually able to calm myself and re-engage constructively.
I recover emotionally from relational stress without lingering resentment.
What usually happens inside you during conflict with someone you care about? (emotions, thoughts, bodily reactions)
What helps you calm down after an argument or emotionally intense interaction?
What do partners tend to misunderstand about how you handle stress or conflict?
I show love mainly through consistent actions rather than emotional expression.
I express care by being present and reliable, even when it is inconvenient.
I believe love is demonstrated through effort more than words.
I am willing to sacrifice personal comfort to support a relationship.
I often put my own needs aside to preserve the relationship.
I feel responsible for maintaining the relationship, even when it is difficult.
When a relationship feels unstable, I tend to give more rather than pull away.
If my efforts are not reciprocated, I reduce how much I invest.
I respond to relational strain by either doubling down or disengaging.
There are clear limits beyond which I would reconsider staying in a relationship.
I remain committed to a relationship even during prolonged difficulty.
What is the most meaningful way you have shown commitment in a relationship?
Describe something you have sacrificed for a relationship that you later questioned or regretted.
What would need to change for you to seriously reconsider staying in a long-term relationship?
I feel desire most strongly when I feel emotionally connected to my partner.
My desire increases when interactions feel exciting or unpredictable.
I can experience desire even without emotional closeness.
Feeling wanted or chosen reliably increases my desire.
Confidence or assertiveness in a partner increases my attraction.
Emotional intensity tends to heighten my desire.
I feel more attracted when one partner takes the lead.
Imbalances in power tend to reduce my desire over time.
I am most attracted to partners who demonstrate emotional awareness.
Consistency and reliability increase my attraction over time.
What reliably increases your desire for a partner over time?
What reliably diminishes your desire, even if the relationship is otherwise stable?
How does confidence, control, or power affect your attraction to someone?
I often adjust my preferences or behavior to match my partner’s expectations.
I resist being defined by relationship roles or expectations.
There are parts of myself I consistently hide or suppress in relationships.
I minimize my own needs to keep relationships stable.
I feel more secure when I have influence over the direction of the relationship.
I tend to assert control rather than adapt when conflict threatens the relationship.
I can move between leading and following in a relationship without discomfort.
Changing roles in a relationship does not feel like a threat to who I am.
Who do you tend to become in romantic relationships compared to when you are on your own?
What parts of yourself do you feel you hide, exaggerate, or protect when you are in a relationship?
When conflict arises, do you tend to adapt to preserve the relationship or assert yourself to preserve your identity? Why?
Who usually has more influence over decisions and direction in your relationships, and how do you feel about that?
How has being in a long-term relationship changed the way you see yourself, for better or worse?

followups.prompt: When I don’t get a quick reply, my mind tends to fill in worst-case meanings.
If a partner wants frequent emotional check-ins, I feel pressured or confined.
I feel uneasy when I’m not the one setting the direction in a relationship.
I often go along with what a partner wants even when I disagree internally.
I use humor or distraction to reduce tension instead of staying with the conflict.
